chapter.title: Tools
chapter.para: The Tools section of the Administration tab is a tool box useful for the day-to-day administration of PMB.

sect1.title: Database cleanup
sect1.para: Database cleanup enables you to remove unused or redundant data, to purge your database of unused authorities.

Here you can also optimize your database by re-indexing it. Removing data from the database frees more space inside the datafile on the server. This is the only way to maintain a high level of performance from your database server.
Caution : after a database cleanup, always perform a database optimization by clicking on Administration > Tools > MySQL maintenance > Optimize the tables (this will reconstruct the MySQL indexes)

sect1.title: SQL queries
sect1.para: SQL queries are SQL commands lines written in the database.

These SQL queries are created or updated in the Administration tab. They are also enabled for users with access privileges in Reporting. For more details on the Reporting tab, please read the chapter Reporting in the PMB user's guide.
Every stored procedure is shown in an array line. You can edit them by clicking on their title, or execute them by clicking on the run button in the left margin.
You can add parameters : this will allow you to run your stored procedures immediately on screen.
Let's symplify matters.
Suppose I'm a librarian with no SQL knowledge and I want a query that will get me the total count of current loans to borrowers over 65 years old.

I ask my systems administrator for a stored procedure. He creates a query called "Current loans / > 65 years old" (title example). The SQL code for the query is a simple ""SELECT COUNT (*) FROM empr, prets WHERE pret.empr_id=empr_id AND (2006-empr_year>=65)"

I can access the query created by the systems administrator from the Reporting tab. However for my statistics, I need the same information but for borrowers aged 30 to 65 and under 30 years. Furthermore, I must run my query every year. In 2007 the previous query will not give the correct results.

The systems administrator will then create a query with some parameters enclosed between double exclamation marks like !!current_year!! The parameter title may be something like "Please, enter the current year"

Stored procedures are among the advanced features of PMB. To create them you need to have a good knowledge of MySQL syntax, to use them simply access Reporting > Reports > SQL Queries. This high degree of customization is rarely directly available to the user in proprietary softwares.

sect2.title: Examples of stored procedure usage
sect2.para: To find out the names of fields to use in your queries open the documentation page on the nucleus of PMB. It lists and describes all the tables of the database, the various fields and their attributes :

sect3.title: Stored procedures : creating a query according to items status
sect3.programlisting: select idcode, codestat_libelle, count(*) as Nombre from exemplaires, docs_codestat, docs_statut where idcode=expl_codestat and expl_section in (!!section!!) and expl_statut='!!status!!' group by idcode, codestat_libelle order by idcode
sect3.para: All you have to do is to enter your settings for !!statut!! and !!section!! by clicking on "Configure parameters".

sect3.title: Using your own custom fields in queries

para.emphasis: I have created a Purchase_year text field for copies in Items > new field. I would like to use it for my statistics, but I can't find the field in the tables.
Here is the query I have created to get the number of items using the statistical code :

para.programlisting: select idcode, codestat_libelle, count(*) as Nombre from exemplaires, docs_codestat where idcode=expl_codestat group by idcode, codestat_libelle order by idcode

para.emphasis: What must I do when I execute the query to display only the items purchased in year y ?

sect3.para: Custom fields do not appear as fields in the database but are written within various tables.
For an item's field, you will have to add in the FROM clause of your query : expl_custom_values, expl_custom, and to specify jointures and condition, the filter in the WHERE clause :
EXPLANATION: filter : after creating a query parameter, Click on "Configure parameters" to indicate it's a parameter and define input options.
EXPLANATION: The name of your custom field
EXPLANATION: the jointure between the items table and the one with your items custom data.
EXPLANATION: the jointure between field names table and field values table.
The final query looks like this :
sect3.programlisting: select idcode, codestat_libelle, count(*) as Nombre from exemplaires, expl_custom_values, expl_custom, docs_codestat where idcode=expl_codestat and expl_custom_small_text='!!purchase_year_param!!' and name='Purchase_year' and expl_id=expl_custom_origine and expl_custom_champ=idchamp group by idcode, codestat_libelle order by idcode
sect3.para: WARNING : Carriage return is not supported in queries.

sect3.title: Exchanging your stored procedures
sect3.para: The PMB Users' wiki is a pool where users can freely post their advice for other users.
Do not hesitate to refer to it : http://www.sigb.net/wiki

sect1.title: Database update
sect1.para: Whenever you update PMB, you replace all the files in the PMB installation directory with those of a new version downloaded from www.sigb.net. But this update affects PMB only and not your database. To update the structure of your database, use Tools > Database update. This update does not destroy anything. You won't lose any information and while you will benefit from the latest new features of PMB, you have the assurance the integrity of your data will be preserved.
sect1.remark: Tools > Database update is a must after updating to a new version of PMB.
sect1.para: Click on the message Click here to start update to see if your database needs updating.

figure.title: Database updates have to be done

sect1.para: In all the screens following (the more your PMB version is old, the more the updates will be numerous), Click on the link Click here to continue.

figure.title: A screen capture displaying various update actions and their results

sect1.para: Continue to click on the message Click here to continue until the message "Your database is up to date in version X.X appears (this version number is not the same as the PMB version number). The database update process is now completed.

sect1.title: Tables description
sect1.para: This tables description corresponds to the basic description of the database MySQL tables. A more detailed documentation is available at http://localhost/pmb/doc/noyau
sect1.remark: "localhost" and "pmb" need to be adapted according to your configuration. "localhost" is the address of your computer or the server where PMB is installed ; "pmb" refers to the installation directory of PMB.

sect1.title: MySQL maintenance
sect1.para: You will find here an interface to the main maintenance tools of MySQL : checking, analyzing, repairing and optimizing tables.
Note. Optimising MySQL does not correspond to re-indexing accessible from Database cleanup. PMB manages its own data index.
There are four MySQL maintenance tools :

listitem.para: repair tables. Allows you to repair the database, if the checking or analysing tools report errors.
optimize tables. Optimization allows you to increase the MySQL performance. You should do it regularly.

sect1.title: Parameters
sect1.para: This tool gives you access various parameters like the name of your library that will be used on all documents created by PMB, displaying the weather in the OPAC, as well as various parameters relating to the ergonomy or even the very structure of the application.
Don't change a parameter value unless you know exactly the effect it will generate, make a backup beforehand.

The parameters types are listed on the screen. To display the various parameters corresponding to a given type, click on the + icon to expand it. Similarly, you can use the - icon to collapse the expanded type shown on the screen.
To change a parameter value, click on the line corresponding to the parameter.
Once you have saved the changes to your parameter value, the parameter list is displayed again at the same place where you left it. The last changed parameter is highlighted with another colour.

sect2.title: Retrieving the values of a parameter within another parameter
sect2.para: Important : You can use one parameter value in another parameter. For example : if you wish to use the parameter value of type borrowers card sub-type biblio_name in type membership reminder notice sub-type fdp , enter $borrowers card_biblio_name : in fdp, and you'll get this as result "The officer in charge of $borrowers card_biblio_name". The syntax is as follows $typeparam_sstypeparam. To retrieve this information click on a parameter, the first two lines indicate the parameter type and sub-type respectively.
